Alex,
If an individual maps to a point evaluation of the design space, an=
d the local jacobian of the fitness landscape is such that an added local g=
radient based sub-optimization task follows a trajectory resulting in an im=
proved fitness associated w/ an updated individual, would that satisfy the =
classification requirements associated w/ "implicit evolved embryogeny"? Al=
so, would you consider uploading your updated version of Hyperneat used in =
your study to the group file repository?
Thanks,
Andy

--- In neat@yahoogro=
ups.com, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> =C2=A0 I'm not =
100% sure to get the whole meaning of your question, so I might answer a bi=
t off-target ^^
> 
> =C2=A0 In that paragraph about the taxonomy (end of pa=
ge 4), I mention "local information". It's not a gradient, as in "gradient =
based optimization", that is, a clue on the local geometry of the objective=
 function. By "local information", I mean, *any* kind of local feedback of =
the behavior of the phenotype. If we optimize a plane wing, it could be, sa=
y, the local air pressure. If we optimize a heat exchanger, it would be loc=
al heath flux. If we optimize a water pipe network, it would the local wate=
r flux and pressure.
> 
> 
> =C2=A0Then, does this local information feebac=
k turns "external non-evolved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved embryogeny=
" ? It's quite a fuzzy territory, if you ask me. Let's say you decode the g=
enotype as a transformation of an initial phenotype to a final one. You hav=
e many many ways to do this, and you can have genotype as a very flexible t=
ransformation (many many development steps, each doing small changes in all=
 possible ways) or a very inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc transformat=
ion step). So between "external non-evolved embryogeny" and "implicit evolv=
ed embryogeny", I believe there is a whole gradient of possibilities rather=
 than a sharp border between the two. Actually, to have a trully "implicit =
evolved embryogeny", it would unbounded development. But in practice, allow=
ing a few steps of development brings a lot of flexibility for a genotype, =
so it's a rethoritical remark.
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> Alex
> 
> 
> _____________=
___________________

> Alex,
> Thank you for the=
 link! Question: In your opinion, does the added presence of local gradient=
-based optimization of the design space transition the classification defin=
ition from "external non-evolved embryogeny" to "implicit evolved embryogen=
y"? BTW, I am attracted to your more flexible taxonomy, as I have never bee=
n fully comfortable with the spatial transformation constraint assumption.
=
> Thanks,
> Andy
>
